PRE-MARKET JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Australia is closed for holiday
content:
JAPAN

Sharp (6753 JT)
- S&P raised Co. credit rating one notch to B+ from BB-; outlook revised to positive from stable. (Newswires)

Taiyo Nippon (4091 JT)
- Co. is seen as leading bidder for Linde/Praxair’s divestments valued at USD 4bln. (Newswires)

Apple Suppliers
- Apple warned suppliers of a 20% reduction in component orders for iPhones launching later this year. (Newswires)

Automakers
- US President Trump refused to endorse the G7 communique and stated the US is looking at tariffs on autos flooding the market. (Newswires)

Other News
- Ruling coalition-backed candidate Hanazumi won the Niigata gubernatorial election, which is seen as a win for PM Abe’s confidence amid cronyism accusations and government’s agenda of reopening reactors which have passed safety reviews. (Mainichi)


SOUTH KOREA

Kia Motors (000270 KS)
- Co. to recall 508k cars in US due to air bag defects. (Newswires)

SK Telecom (017670 KS)
- Co. agrees with a Shenzhen based firm on cooperation in development of products and solutions for live drone streaming. (Yonhap)

Geopolitical
- US President Trump and North Korean Leader Kim arrived in Singapore ahead of the summit on Tuesday. (ABC)
- US President Trump stated that he believes North Korean Leader Kim will do something positive and added that he has one time shot but thinks it will go well. (Newswires)
- North Korea said summit with US will discuss permanent and firm peace regime, as well as denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula. (KCNA)

Other News
- South Korean financial authorities plan stricter anti-money laundering rules ahead of next year’s assessment by an intergovernmental organization to tackle illicit fund flows. (Newswires)
- Hyundai Research Institute think tank sees the South Korean economy to grow 2.8% this year. (Yonhap)

ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights Include New Zealand Manufacturing Activity, Japanese Money Supply and Machine Orders, Australia closed for holiday
North Korea said summit with US will discuss permanent and firm peace regime, as well as denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
G7

US President Trump refused to endorse the G7 communique which he stated was due to false statements made by Canadian PM Trudeau who he criticized as being dishonest and weak, while he also suggested the US is looking at tariffs on autos flooding the market. This was in response to comments from Canadian PM Trudeau that Canada would impose retaliatory tariffs against US and warned that Canada would not be pushed around. (Newswires)

G7 official communique which was backed by all countries apart from the US, acknowledged free, fair and mutually beneficial trade was a vital engine for growth and jobs, while the countries will strive to lower tariff barriers and subsidies, as well as continue fighting protectionism. (Newswires)

German Chancellor Merkel said have agreed with the US to review trade ties and tariffs, while she added that the aim is to avoid US tariffs on autos. Merkel further stated that EU will reassess if US imposes auto tariffs and that they must seek own path if negotiations fail, while she also commented that EU has prepared counter measures against US tariffs on steel and aluminium. (Newswires)
 

ASIA-PAC

Chinese CPI (May) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.8%). (Newswires)
Chinese PPI (May) Y/Y 4.1% vs. Exp. 3.9% (Prev. 3.4%)


UK/EU

Scottish First Minister Sturgeon said she is convinced that persuading majority of Scottish voters regarding independence is within reach but added should not concentrate on when independence will occur and instead focus on how to persuade others on it. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Poland at A-, outlook stable. (Newswires)

DBRS affirmed Germany at AAA, stable trend and affirmed Poland at A, Stable trend. (Newswires)

Switzerland voted in referendum against motion to abolish traditional banking and only permitting money created by SNB, which was as expected. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (8 Jun) 1062 (Prev. 1060). (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia reportedly increased oil production by 100k in June ahead of incoming sanctions on Iran. (WSJ)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump and North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un have arrived in Singapore ahead of the summit on Tuesday. (ABC)

US President Trump stated that he believes North Korean Leader Kim will do something positive and added that he has one time shot but thinks it will go well. Elsewhere, President Trump stated some of the other G7 members agreed with his view that having Russia back in the group would be positive. (Newswires)

North Korea said summit with US will discuss permanent and firm peace regime, as well as denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula. (KCNA)


US

White House Chief of Staff Kelly told some senators last week that the White House was a miserable place to work. (The Hill / NYT)
 

MARKET RECAP

Following a very rangebound overnight session for the US futures, as European traders sat at their desk, some selling was seen in the ES which consolidated around the 2755 level before pairing back those losses in a gradual climb for most of the session and finishing higher as markets await G7 updates. Apple was said to warn suppliers about a 20% decline in iPhone parts order, according to Nikkei, and now expects shipments of 80mln units for the new phones, down from the 100mln unit orders it ordered the previous year. On the earnings front, Broadcom (AVGO) earnings slightly beat expectations on EPS front, and revenues were in line, but guidance on Q3 wireless revenue was weak, which saw the stock lower by 3% and trading at the bottom of the SPX & NDX. Monster Beverages (MNST) traded at the top of the SPX and supported the consumer staples sector on Friday following its AGM, where it stated its US business is showing strong momentum and said there is room to increase prices later this year to offset the higher aluminium costs following tariffs. JP Morgan’s (JPM), Amazon’s (AMZN) and Berkshire’s (BRK.A) candidate to lead their joint healthcare venture stated he would not lead the entity as he is focused on his current CEO position at Geisinger Health System. M&A flow was very light today, however during hours CNBC reported Dialog Semiconductor (DLE GY) is in talks for touch screen maker Synaptics (SYNA), but the initial offer of USD 59/shr was rejected. Elsewhere, CNBC’s Faber reported that Comcast’s (CMCSA) bid for 21st Century Fox (FOXA) is coming on June 13th. Elsewhere, NY Post reported that the legal battle for CBS (CBS) & National Amusements has been set for October 3rd. SPX +0.31%, NDX 0.00%, DJI +0.30%.

Treasuries were pretty much unchanged on Friday as investors have been cautiously awaiting for a G7 outcome and ahead of FOMC and ECB next week. Most of the action was concentrated in the front end of the curve though yields were lower by less than c.1bps. Spreads were mixed, 2s10s were wider by c.1bps at settlement. US 10YR T-notes futures (Sep 2018) were unchanged at 119-19.
